title: Corrected Reticulocyte Percentage/Reticulocyte Production Index (RPI)
description: Assesses bone marrow response to anemia by correcting reticulocyte count for degree of anemia and maturation time

parameters.name: normal_hematocrit
parameters.description: Normal hematocrit reference value (typically 45% for adults)

parameters.name: rbc_count
parameters.description: Red blood cell count for absolute reticulocyte count calculation

ranges.interpretation: RPI <0.5 indicates very decreased reticulocyte production, suggesting bone marrow failure or severe nutritional deficiency
RPI <2 indicates inadequate bone marrow response to anemia, suggesting hypoproliferative anemia
RPI 2-3 indicates borderline bone marrow response, may suggest early recovery or mild bone marrow dysfunction
RPI >3 indicates appropriate bone marrow response to anemia, suggesting hemolytic or hemorrhagic anemia

references: Koepke JA. Laboratory hematology practice. New York: Churchill Livingstone; 1989.
Hillman RS, Ault KA. Hematology in clinical practice. New York: McGraw-Hill; 2002.
Nathan DG, Orkin SH, Look AT, Ginsburg D. Nathan and Oski's Hematology of Infancy and Childhood. 6th ed. Philadelphia: W.B. Saunders; 2003.
Bain BJ. Blood Cells: A Practical Guide. 4th ed. Oxford: Blackwell Publishing; 2006.
formula: RPI = (Reticulocyte % × Measured Hct / Normal Hct) / Maturation Factor. Maturation factors: Hct ≥35%=1.0, 25-34%=1.5, 20-24%=2.0, <20%=2.5
notes: Normal RPI range: 0.5-2.5% in healthy individuals
RPI >3 with anemia indicates RBC loss with increased reticulocyte production
RPI <2 with anemia suggests hypoproliferative anemia
Recent blood transfusions can affect results
Maturation time correction accounts for premature release of reticulocytes in severe anemia
Use in conjunction with other hematologic parameters for complete assessment
